content: BAN ON TRADE OFFICIAL REPRESENTING OR ADVISING FOREIGN ENTITIES. The text chunk discusses amendments to sections 207(f)(2) of title 18, United States Code, and section 141(b) of the Trade Act of 1974 regarding the representation of foreign entities in trade negotiations. It limits appointments of individuals who have represented, aided, or advised foreign entities from being appointed as United States Trade Representative or Deputy United States Trade Representative. The amendments restrict the appointment of individuals who have represented foreign entities from being appointed as United States Trade Representative, Deputy United States Trade Representative, Secretary of Commerce, or Commissioner of the International Trade Commission. The amendments apply to individuals appointed on or after the enactment of the Act. The amendments limit the appointment of individuals who have represented foreign entities from being appointed to certain key positions in the government. The amendment restricts former government officers or employees from representing foreign entities in matters involving the United States, with penalties outlined in section 216 of title 18, United States Code. The amendment prohibits former government officers or employees from representing foreign entities in the United States within 5 years of their service termination, with specified exceptions. Foreign entities engaging in representation or advice related to matters involving the United States may face punishment under section 216 of this title. The restrictions apply to the President of the United States and individuals subject to subsections (c), (d), or (e). The definitions provided in this subsection clarify terms such as compensation, government of a foreign country, foreign political party, United States, and State. The amendment expands the definition of 'State' to include the District of Columbia and other US territories. Amendment to Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code, prohibits the misappropriation of a person's name in connection with lobbying to influence Congress. DISCLOSURES OF VISITS TO MEMBERS AND SENATORS: The Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate will establish a registry for lobbyists to record visits to Members of Congress, including the date and subject of the visit. The registry will be open to the public starting January 1, 1996.
